The very first day, the speed of sync is hundreds of blk/s, now it becomes 10blk/s. Not sure what's going on.

I'm not an expert nor am I part of the Erigon team, but I suspect two things are happening.

Remember, the sync happens from block zero forward in time.

1. The number of transactions per block increases massively over time and
2. The complexity of the transactions increases massively over time. 

These two combine to slow things down the later in the chain's history the sync gets.

I would close this issue as you're describing expected behavior, but perhaps someone else can chime in.

@farmage  In my case, the disk write is ~20MB/s for couple of seconds, then reduces to less than 1MB/s for couple of seconds. Not sure what's going on.

"RAM 32Gb" - no magic, mainnet state is ~80gb and when it grows over RAM - you will start face more and more page-faults (page cache misses). "read-ahead strategy" is not easy for turing-complete-smart-contracts, we have some - but very limited. and page-cache-miss speed is limited by disk-latency (not by throughput): faster disk or bigger ram will help.

"after 10 minutes everything goes back" - it's also about page-cache-misses - when you re-start you re-execution some last blocks - and you see it as "fast speed" because no page-misses (same blocks was just executed). 

can a bit optimize state size by - manual db compaction: "integration mdbx_to_mdbx" or "mdbx_dump|mdbx_load" (see ./cmd/integraion/readme.md).

- run: integration stage_exec --batchSize=1g
